utterances: Kelly Beatty is senior contributing editor of Sky and Telescope magazine.
There is a black-and-white photograph that's one of the most enduring images of the Great Depression.
It's called ""Migrant Mother."" It shows a poor farm worker, her hand touching her face in worry.
Two ragged children clutch her shoulders, and a baby is wrapped in cloth in the mother's lap.
This photo was taken by Dorothea Lange.
A new book documents hundreds of Lange's photos of the dust bowl and the Depression and the descriptions she wrote of them.
It's called ""Daring to Look.
The author is Anne Whiston Spirn, and she joins us now from WBUR in Boston.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you.
That image called ""Migrant Mother"" is one of the most-reproduced photographs in history.
Dorothea Lange took it in California in 1936.
She had a job working for one of the New Deal agencies, the Farm Security Administration.
I wonder: Why did the government send out photographers to those places?
In the beginning, the first job of the photographers was to show the conditions that existed across the country.
Then as the 1930s went on and the government programs had been implemented, her job shifted to photographing the success, presumably, of these programs.
Of course, Lange being Lange found that things weren't working out in the field quite as well as the bureaucrats would like.
So she took photographs by 1939 not only of the successful programs but also of conditions that continued to persist.
You focus on the year 1939, after she took ""Migrant Mother."" Why 1939?
In 1939, she started writing longer reports to go with her photographs, which were really stories from the field.
Would you turn to one of those photos?
Sure.
Describe for me the picture, if you would, and then read for me from Dorothea Lange's notes.

Well, there's a picture of a woman named Queen, and along with Queen is a group of her fellow farm wives ranged across the steps to the church, and Lange says: Women of the congregation on the church steps with brooms and buckets.
Date: July 5, 1939.
Subject: Annual cleaning-up day at Wheeley's(ph) Church.
Accidentally learned at Gordonton(ph) that everybody in the community was gathering at the church, going to take their dinner.
Farm women of all ages, men and children, one six-months-old baby and one woman on two crutches were still there finishing up the cleaning at about 2:30.
Had to talk to the head deacon to get permission to photograph.
They very much want to have a print showing the church and the grounds, very proud of their church, spacious, well-shaded church yard and very proud of the fact that they keep everything so tidy.
We came across a quote of Dorothea Lange talking about what motivates her.
She said no country has ever closely scrutinized itself visually that I know of.
I know what we could make of it if people only thought we could dare look at ourselves.
What's your favorite picture?
All along the main streets, storefronts have been transformed into places where products are on display, and in many cases being given away.
But not everyone thinks boosting Blunt from whip to leader would be such a good idea.
Michigan Republican Thaddeus McCotter spoke from his district office in Livonia.
There is a concern among some members, and I would be one of them, that the headlines will read `Republican Party considers problem so big, they promote everybody.'
McCotter supports Boehner, who, he says, has credibility that the current leadership doesn't have in the effort to clean up the image of corruption in the party.
And an interesting twist is that Boehner used to be in the House leadership but lost his post in 1998 after he was blamed for doing a less-than-stellar job selling the party's policies to the public.
Boehner was an ally of Newt Gingrich and no buddy of Tom DeLay's.
But McCotter says Boehner's history doesn't necessarily hurt him.
Having had a leadership position in the past and having lost it, I think he's been chastened and will be very responsive to the conference.
And so right now, the race for House majority leader seems to be shaping up to be Blunt vs. Boehner, but that's not exactly to everyone's liking.

There's a lot of grumbling going on among rank-and-file Republicans who feel choosing between a current member of leadership and a former member of leadership won't quite provide the fresh face they were hoping for in this election year.

And some say there's still plenty of time for a dark-horse candidate to pull forward in the race, but the fact that Blunt and Boehner both have pretty high statures in the party means it would be difficult for another candidate to pull votes from either.
Andrea Seabrook, NPR News, Washington.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Coming up, a TV critic watches hours of personal-finance shows to tell us which are worth your time and money.
But first, when Wall Street collapsed, Americans got religion: No more spending sprees; saving every penny has become a new sexy.
With me now is Christie Pearson-Wohlwend.
She's 45 years old and became a saver five years ago.
So, five years ago, Christie, Wall Street was, well, it was doing really well.
Why did you begin saving then when you weren't saving earlier?
Well, I just really had an epiphany, and you know, I was living on the ragged edge of my finances, and I just couldn't do it anymore.
I couldn't balance my checkbook; checks were bouncing.
You know, I was in debt, and I just thought, I can't do this anymore.
I just can't.
I've got a life to live.
Uh-huh.
And so, you were basically living beyond your means.
I was living beyond my means.
And I've always work hard, and I've got a graduate degree, and I mean, I was doing the right things, except I wasn't thinking well about my finances.
I wasn't able to sort of figure it out.
And so, I had to create strategies in my life that worked for me to get balance back into my life.
And tell us some of the things that you did.
What are some of your tips?
Well, I worked on - number one, I faced them.
I looked at all the debt I had.
I looked at, you know, how my checking account was running.
And I thought, you know, I've got to create strategies.
So, my number-one strategy was looking at all my debt, and I, you know, took the ones that were the lowest balance.
So, my store cards were the lowest balances.
And I just paid the other ones, you know, on time and with a minimum, but paid over the amount on the small ones, on the store cards.
Got those paid off and closed the account.
And then, got the next one, focused on the next one, and focused on the next one, and then - and the big cards, you know, the Discover and the MasterCard, were at one point $10,000.
So, I looked at that, said, I have X amount of money to pay off that, going to divide that by how many months I want it pay off, and just really dedicated to paying those off.
I teach in the evening, took that money and just dedicated it to paying it off.
So, it sounds like a lot of discipline on your part.
I guess it was discipline and - I - yeah...
You had to make up for the lack of discipline or...
I don't know if I've - I - yeah.
I guess it was.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, so, do you feel deprived at all?
Do you feel like, gosh, I'm just not living the high life anymore?
I'm living this...
No, no. In fact, I feel the opposite.

I feel like I'm so free now, because before it feels like this huge cloud over you, and you feel like, I'm just not in control of this, I don't have a sense of this, and it feels frustrating, and you feel incompetent, and you feel it's a huge shame.
You know, I had a graduate degree, had a successful job, and I couldn't quite figure this out, this area of my life, out.
So, you used to be many tens of thousands of dollars in debt.
Now, how much are you saving every month?
Probably about $200 a month, something like that.
Just able to take that money and put in pure savings.
I also - you know, with my employer, I have a 403b, and you know, I have savings that way, but this is just pure rainy-day cushion money.
You became a saver five years ago, so that means you were in debt for most of your adult life.
Yeah.
What would you splurge on?
What would you spend your money on?
It was the trip to Target or to Wal-Mart or, you know, (unintelligible), that I would just, you know, spend $150 easily, $200 easily, several times a month.
And yes, some of the items were necessities, but some of them weren't necessities.
And I could very easily diddle a lot of money away very quickly.
Those were my downfalls in terms of spending too much and not saving enough.
Christie Pearson-Wohlwend is a successfully reformed spendthrift living in San Diego, California.
Christie, thank you.
You're welcome.
Peter Negron was only 11 when he lost his father, who worked on the 88th floor.
Today, Negron is a college student, and trying to share his father's lessons with his younger brother.

Really strange moment - Mike Pence turned to what seemed like an unlikely ally for a Republican.
That's Bill Clinton.
He referred to something the former president said while campaigning for his wife this week.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Even former President Bill Clinton calls Obamacare a crazy plan.
But Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine want to build on Obamacare.
They want to expand it into a single-payer program.
And for all the world, Hillary Clinton just thinks Obamacare is a good start.
Did Bill Clinton call Obamacare a crazy plan?
